intro.description:
This cheat sheet shows you how to model two different sources and create a view that joins data from both sources. In this example, a JDBC source table and Flat File source table are used.
Note: These steps are sequential and require you to complete or skip each step before being allowed to Perform, Complete or Skip the next step.
To learn more about using cheat sheets click the help icon above.
Press "Click to Begin" button below to start.

item.title: Create JDBC Source Connection
item.description:
This following action creates a JDBC Connection profile.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to launch the connection profile wizard.
-- >
-- > You may skip this step if you have already created this connection profile.
============================================================

item.title: Create Source From JDBC Connection
item.description:
This following action creates a relational model from importing table data via your JDBC connection profile.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to launch the JDBC import wizard.
-- >
-- > You may skip this step if you have already imported this model.
============================================================

item.title: Test JDBC Table Data
item.description:
This following action allows you to preview data from your newly modeled JDBC source.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to preview data from your source table.
-- > Click the browse "..." button to select the newly created source table
-- > Click OK to execute the query
-- > Results of the query will displayed in the SQL Results view
-- > You may skip this step.
============================================================

item.title: Create Flat File Connection
item.description:
This following action creates an ODA Flat File connection profile.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to create a Flat File connection profile.
-- >
-- > You may skip this step if you have already created this connection profile.
============================================================

item.title: Create Source From Flat File Connection
item.description:
This following action creates a relational model from importing table data via your Flat File connection profile. This action results in the creation of both a source and a view model. The source model will contain a generated text file procedure which will be used in the definition of the view table containing a generated SQL statement designed to query your flat file.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to launch the Flat File import wizard..
-- >
-- > You may skip this step if you have already imported this model.
============================================================

item.title: Test Flat File Table Data
item.description:
This following action allows you to preview data from your newly generated Flat File view table.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to preview data from your flat file.
-- > Click the browse "..." button to select the newly created view table
-- > Click OK to execute the query
-- > Results of the query will displayed in the SQL Results view
-- > You may skip this step.
============================================================

item.title: Create View Model
item.description:
This following action creates an empty view model.
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to create a view model.
-- >
-- > You may skip this step if you have already created your view model.
============================================================

item.description:
This following action creates
============================================================
-- > Press "Click to Perform" button below to create a view table.
-- >
-- > You may skip this step if you have already created a view table.
============================================================
